values: Barring anything unforeseen coming up in the background check (which I doubt, because I am both honest and boring), I will be starting my new job at EMD Serono on August 12.  For a great boss and big fat raise and great work.  Huzzah!  And a 44 mile drive each way through nasty traffic.  Huz . . . well, no.  But that's okay. Even with the hour+ commute each way this is a terrific thing, because I got laid off from Vertex on January 17.  I was on the payroll till February 4 . . . and the lump sum severance package paid me through mid-May . . . and generous Massachusetts unemployment got us through after that till mid-June . . . and the weeks since then have been soul-killing.  Just . . . crushing.  Meanwhile I made it to the final round of seven jobs, in the time between, and none of them worked out. None of those seven jobs were anywhere even close to as awesome as my previous job, much less anywhere near as terrific as this one -- a big jump up in salary and responsibility, yay!  But . . . I was desperate and scared and I often applied to roles two or even three levels below me, and I would've taken each and any of them if I'd been offered, just to be working SOMEWHERE again.  I always figured I'd someday be grateful for the experience of being rejected seven times in a row (more in that later) but now, with that rejection leading to a better job even than the one I'd gotten laid off from, I am THRILLED.  But more than that, relieved.  And hopefully done with being scared. You'd think that my having watched so many better people than I get laid off, in the seven years I was at Pfizer, would have made this easier.  Or the fact that I hated, hated, hated my job at the end.  Or the fact that I'd already started interviewing elsewhere by the time it happened.  Nope.  One of the only things that really helped was all my friends confiding that they, or their spouses, had also gotten laid off in the past and they never told anyone.  (I didn't really tell anyone either.)  One of my best friends not only told me that her husband had gotten laid off back when they were living in NYC, but that it took him SIX WHOLE MONTHS to find a new job (me too; the offer came on July 17) and that they completely blew through their savings in that time (luckily we have not touched ours). Complicating all of this is that Steve and I made the supremely and completely uncharacteristically irrational move of buying that lovely place up in New Hampshire after all . . . a couple weeks after I got laid off.  (The previous owners ended up having to sell at a loss in a short sale, and contacted us to see if we still wanted it.  For the amazing price they were offering, we did.)  Negotiating the short sale with the bank over a six month period was hard enough while I still had a job, and completely nerve-wracking once I didn't.  Boy, don't ever redo a mortgage at the last minute, on one income instead of two, if you want to keep your sanity.  I don't regret it one bit, but I do have to wonder what kind of crack we were smoking at the time. Anyway.  It's already nice to know that this dark time is coming to an end.  I can't pretend I'm looking forward to two plus hours of driving every day (especially in my beloved stick shift cars).  But hey, it sure as fuck beats the alternative.  Everything is just slightly easier now.  We are just a tiny bit calmer, a wee bit happier, every day. Oddly enough things had already started to get a little better around about the time we went up to New Hampshire for Fourth of July.  That's probably the best anniversary of either of us could have asked for . . . but the job offer could trump that.

so, for obvious reasons (most of which can be found in my whiny posts over the past six months), I find this pretty dang awesome.

even awesomer is the fact that the first time I saw it was on the Johnson School alums Facebook page, with about 350 "likes". 

ah, b-students.  and to think people say we have no sense of irony (or humor).

it feels strange to post here again, after so long.  I can't promise I'll keep it up.  I also can't promise not to do the annoying "here's what I was up to all this past year" post, even though I usually find those so annoying and apologetic (what, you didn't post for a while?  um, yeah, we all survived).  so, random thoughts in no particular order:

- connor is five months old and gorgeous.  I stopped posting right when I  got pregnant with him (completely coincidentally) so maybe there are readers out  there that haven't heard my many hellish stories about that time.   not that there were any complications whatsoever from the pregnancy itself (not  even a kidney stone, unlike last time!) unless you count the wholly  unexpected experience of being clinically depressed.  never had that  before, in my life.  never even came close, quite frankly.  never want  to go through it again.  when all the crying and not eating and not  sleeping was done, and I was holding a beautiful 6 pound 6 ounce baby in  my arms (so much smaller than we wanted him to be!  but perfect all the  same), I was amazed to discover the exact polar opposite of PPD.  it  was like a switch had been thrown and I was myself again.  I didn't even  have the baby blues, the way I did with james.  fucking hormones.  and to top it off  connor is happy, and chill, and calm, and smiley, and placid, and easygoing, and an absolute peach of a baby.  I have  no idea how that happened, given how miserable I was  throughout his entire gestation, but I am thankful every day for it.

- I'm starting a new job july 1.  still in helth-wyzer, but out of IT.  in commercial operations.  my journey towards the dark side is now complete.  I can no longer hide in the ostensibly "good" world of regulatory and medical operations, steadfastly saving the company every last penny I can find; now, my job will be helping the sales force make money.  whatever.  I did my best in development and medical for long enough, people.  I'm not superhuman.

- you do a lot of soul-searching when you're told, on your second day back from maternity leave, that your job has been eliminated.  I thought that I was already as angry at the company as I could possibly be, given the drubbing I'd taken from my boss the previous year.  but this was a new level of rage.  it's not that I harbored any particular illusions that, when the chips were down, I'd still be valued by The Company as if we were all living in the 1950s or something.  I'd seen far, far too many excellent coworkers callously tossed aside over the past five years to be that naive.  but I had worked my tail off, while pregnant and depressed, and I'd expected better.  in the end they never quite had the balls to ACTUALLY lay me off (probably because they knew I would sue their pants off, and quite likely collect a sweet settlement too if the company's own past history is any judge) and as referenced above I managed to find something far better even after they grudgingly gave me a shitty project management job to tide me over with.  still.  I didn't think I could plumb new depths of jadedness but I am even more callous now than before.  

- so why stay?  well, to be able to make the move out of IT and into the business is very, very good.  it looks PHENOMENAL from a resume perspective.  the new job also happens to be very much what I want to learn, and do, and excel at.  and all the things about helth-wyzer that have kept me there over the past three years (easy commute; incredible benefits; personal trainer; sweet paycheck) are still there.  I'm still learning good stuff.  I'm still doing good stuff.  but still in all honesty it was pretty surprising to both steve and I that we didn't just leap at the opportunity and make the move to boston.  if I'd actually gotten laid off, well, at a bare minimum we would have been looking at 7-9 months of pay in a lump sum.  probably two to three times that if I'd gotten all lawyered up and sued.  either of those would've gone a long way towards a down payment on a new house.  steve can work from pretty much anywhere as an IBM employee, and even in this tough economy my prospects in the boston area biotechs, after five years supporting development and regulatory operations, looked pretty good.*  on the other hand, the house is just about done, the property is just about landscaped, and we have made tons of great friends with kids in the neighborhood and are really very, very happy where we are.  we basically dithered and sat on the fence long enough for me to find a better job at helth-wyzer and I am not sorry that we did.

- steve has taken up sailing with the husband of one of my good girlfriends, at my incessant urging.  I am SO GLAD.  I have a couple terrific girlfriends in the city, and a couple of newer (terrific) girlfriends in the neighborhood, and he is always great about encouraging me to go and spend time with them.  but he himself doesn't have as many friends in the area (for a number of reasons, many of which begin with the letters I, B and M) so this is one of the few times he has to go off and have guy time.  AND go sailing.  every sunday afternoon.  it's definitely a big time commitment, especially if they all go off and have dinner afterwards, and I'm definitely finding that everyone was right when they told me two kids are really about four times the work of one.  the fact that steve can go off and have some Me Time makes it totally worth it, however.  and let's face it:  when kristine and I take our kids to the SurfSide Club in Greenwich to drink pina coladas and watch our kids scamper around the patio, I'm finding a way to cope.



* I was actually on the shuttle between the two connecticut campuses of bo3ringer ing3lh3im, on my second round of interviews, when I rolled off a voicemail from my soon-to-be boss offering me the job in commercial operations.  I accepted on the spot and then had 2+ more hours of interviews where I had to smile and tell them how excited I really was to work there, honestly, really.  would've felt wildly guilty about that if I hadn't been so freakin' excited.

because I just mowed the lawn with a hand mower and do not want to pack, but instead checked my friends page and saw  's......



1. First thing you wash in the shower?
Face.  Unless I'm at work (more likely) in which case it's hair.

2. What colour is your favourite hoodie?
Black.

3. Would you kiss the last person you kissed again?
For the rest of my life!

4. Do you plan outfits?
Yup.  Usually many days in the future, for fun, in a boring meeting.  But they're almost always planned at some point regardless.

5. How are you feeling RIGHT now?
Cheerful.

6. What’s the closest thing to you that's red?
My hair.  Sort of.

7. Tell me about the last dream you remember having?
I couldn't find James.  I knew he was okay, I just couldn't find him.

8. Did you meet anybody new today?
A woman in the elevator at work.

9. What are you craving right now?
Nothing, oddly.

10. Do you floss?
Often.

11. What comes to mind when I say cabbage?
Baby rabbits hiding in the leaves.  No idea why.

12. Are you emotional?
Definitely, at times.  Though never at work.

13. Have you ever counted to 1,000?
Not that I recall.  And I imagine I would.

14. Do you bite into your ice cream or just lick it?
Lick it, even off the spoon (kinda gross I know).

15. Do you like your hair?
Yup.  It's pricey and time-consuming to take care of it but I like it.

16. Do you like yourself?
Yup.  I also irritate and embarrass myself, but that's par for the course.

17. Would you go out to eat with George W. Bush?
Yup.  Couldn't pass up that opportunity, much as I hate the man.

18. What are you listening to right now?
The breeze coming through my dining room windows.

19. Do you believe in God?
*A* God, yes.

20. Would you go sky diving?
Probably, if someone else were paying for it.  Steve did once.  He doesn't make it sound like it's worth the expense.

21. Do you like cottage cheese?
Yup.

22. Have you ever met a celebrity?
Bill Murray, who said my shoes were way too large (not funny w/o context).  Otherwise it's John Cleese, Liddy Dole, Sylvester Stallone and Chelsea Clinton (whose glass of sauvignon blanc came from the same bottle as mine).

23. Do you rent movies often?
Netflix gives us new stuff about once or twice a month.  It was more often when I was on maternity leave.

24. Is there anything sparkly in the room you're in?
My engagement ring and my right-hand ring. 

25. How many countries have you visited?
11 (Germany, Italy, Austria, Hungary, Canada, France, Mexico, Aruba, Brazil, Italy, Bermuda).

26. Have you made a prank phone call?
Yup.  Didn't everyone go through seventh grade?

27. Ever been on a train?
Twice a day, five days a week, for the past five years at LEAST.

28. Brown or white eggs?
Do not care. 

29. Do you have a cell phone?
Yup. 

30. Do you use chapstick?
Nope.  Though we're buying the company that makes it so I guess I should start.

31. Do you own a gun?
Nope.  I do enjoy shooting them though.

32. Can you use chopsticks?
Yup.

33. Who are you going to be with tonight?
Steve and James (the latter only until about 7pm when he goes to bed).

34. Are you too forgiving?
Probably the opposite.

35. Ever been in love?
Yup.

36. What is your best friend doing tomorrow?
Nesting with me and his son.  If it's best non-spouse friend, then I imagine she's chilling in Sunset Park and I should call her.

37. Ever have cream puffs?
Yup.

38. Last time you cried?
Night before last in a hotel room in Connecticut, missing James.

39. What was the last question you asked?
"Is there anything else we need to cover?"  Classic scope creep/managing expectations/consulting 101 shit with long-suffering clients and the unholy marriage that is SharePoint and a bastardized quasi-ersatz-DCMI enterprise taxonomy.

40. Favourite time of the year?
Fall.

41. Do you have any tattoos?
Nope.

42. Are you sarcastic?
Usually.

43. Have you ever seen The Butterfly Effect?
Nope, though I wouldn't rule it out.

44. Ever walked into a wall?
Nope.

45. Favourite colour?
Blue?  Dark red?

46. Have you ever slapped someone?
Nope.  Have wanted to though.

47. Is your hair curly?
Nope.  Everyone on my mom's side of the family, and everyone in Steve's family, has curly hair.  James does too.  But I only take after my dad.

48. What was the last CD you bought?
Lily Allen, "It's Not Me, It's You" on iTunes

49. Do looks matter?
Yup.  At least some, to me, and to most people.  Should they?  Nope.

50. Could you ever forgive a cheater?
Probably not.  Luckily I haven't had to.  (That I know of.)

51. Is your phone bill sky high?
Nope.

52. Do you like your life right now?
Yup!  Very much.

53. Do you sleep with the TV on?
Nope.  Can't even have it in the bedroom. 

54. Can you handle the truth?
I guess we all have to handle it every day, don't we?  I don't always like it, no.  

55. Do you have good vision?
Nope.  I'm still up at 10.5 diopters in one eye and only slightly better in the other.  I also have no intention of having LASIK anytime soon.

56. Do you hate or dislike more than 3 people?
Nope.  Exactly three, actually.  One relative, one former friend and one in-law.

57. How often do you talk on the phone?
Several times a day.  Mostly at work though.

58. The last person you held hands with?
Steve, last night, on the way to the bar where his favorite band was playing.

59. What are you wearing?
Half-destroyed Citizens Of Humanity jeans and a sleeveless black silk shirt.

60. What is your favourite animal?
Cat.

61. Where was your default picture taken at?
A little cruising boat on Cayuga Lake, on the second day of business school orientation.  I had met Steve four days prior and was already bummed that he wasn't on the trip and plotting "accidental" ways to run into him when we got back on dry land.

62. Can you hula hoop?
Not well.

63. Do you have a job?
Yup.  For now.  I happen to like it enormously but am not dumb enough to count on it long-term.

64. What was the most recent thing you bought?
My half of lunch with my friend John.

65. Have you ever crawled through a window?
Yup.  Most recent time I remember was coming back from a bar with Steve before we were dating and he'd forgotten his keys and his roommate was sleeping.  It seemed like a good idea at the time.

in a few weeks I will get my eighth boss in less than five years.  in corporate america these days this isn't wholly uncommon (though 8 in <5 years is a little excessive).  it still sucks.

I'm more pissed than usual since this woman made such a show of wanting me in her group -- I've seen your body of work, I know you've been bounced around a lot, but I also know you can deliver and I think you need a home -- blah blah blah.  I can't fault her for leaving -- she's actually taking a bigger and better job elsewhere within the company, which is pretty fucking hard to do these days and therefore quite impressive.  but I'm irked just the same.  I feel like I went out on a limb to work with this woman (especially since I am not exactly any kind of fan female bosses as a rule) and now I have to start all over again once more.

not that the job itself isn't fun.  I seem to have stumbled unwittingly into sales, after avoiding it like the plague all these years and even spending $100k and two years of my life escaping it via b-school instead.  whatever, if that's where I can do the kind of work that I want to do, then so be it.  

we are taking james into the city tomorrow to the car show, and meeting up with steve's old roommate tim who now works for porsche.  there's very little not awesome about that.

I am working from home today (what's my boss going to do, yell at me?) and hoping to get some gardening in before the rain hits.  I'd also like a run (for some reason I was a pathetic excuse for a runner all over the treadmill this week) but it looks like easter sunday is the soonest I can do that.  I think I will need a nice detoxing run after the catholic mass in bronxville, anyway.  I found an old lilly pulitzer dress in the back of my closet that I forgot I bought years ago, and am grateful that I have something cute and spring-ish that cost more than $200 before markdown to wear so that I will be let in the door and not looked wholly down upon.


EDIT:  eighth boss, not seventh.  I forgot about scott, who was my manager for two weeks and who I never actually met in person until long after I'd successfully lobbied to work for rick instead.  he did not take it personally and we get along very well.

this morning on the train I once again got stuck next to a woman who annoys the shit out of me.  unfortunately, her son goes to the same daycare as jamie, and she always takes the 7:58 express, from tuckahoe, and so do I now that I sit on a hallway of coworkers (including my immensely clock-watching new boss, who's cool with me leaving every day at 4:35 to pick up jamie, but who also quite legitimately expects me in by 8:30), I can no longer take any later train.  and the next earliest train is 7:39, which is pretty much impossible for me to catch when daycare only opens at 7:30 and I still have to park the car and then hoof it down the hill to the station after that.  anyway, this woman drives me up the wall because she is the single most negative person I've met so far in 2009.  I honestly wonder why she stays married to her husband if he's truly the asshole that she describes him as.  not that she sounds like a fun person to be married to, but.....last friday's conversation hit its nadir when she talked about how he threatened to "pop her in the mouth" and she supposedly said "go ahead, I dare you."  I don't like to think about the implications of that, nor the possible ethical obligations on me, at that hour of the morning.  and now I can't even escape her -- she used to take the train from the middle cars, but she started moving down to the head cars once she saw that I always go there.  then today, I hid in the middle car area....but she came down to find me.  so that sucked.

then (while nodding in sympathy as she described how despicable her admittedly annoying-sounding in-laws are) I realized I'd completely forgotten to buy my march commuter rail pass. 

thankfully the kind attendant (no doubt seeing my hapless plight and taking pity on me) took my february one away instead.

long day at work.  not too bad though.

end of the day.  making lasagna tonight to use up the last of some leftover bolognese.  figure I'll pick up more lasagna noodles from the italian place in grand central since they're extra special yummy.  unfortunately -- AFTER I buy the spinach and ricotta and parmesan and some random yummy cheese just for the hell of it, at the other overpriced stores there -- I find out the italian place is all out of lasagna noodles.  and the closest grocery store I know of near grand central is a seedy gristedes on 41st and 2nd which really creeps me out.  so I'll have to hit the grocery store on the way home anyway.  so I'm carrying a big ol' bag of overpriced groceries around for no reason.

don't know why but this irritates me a bit and I decide I deserve a treat.  I pick up a gelato.  mmm, key lime pie gelato.

then I see, gelato in hand, that I'm actually in time to catch the earlier train.  and there's a convenience store across the street from the train station that might have lasagna noodles, which would give me enough time to get up the hill to pick up jamie by the 5:30 deadline too.  what the hell, worth a shot.

on the train, as it literally pulls out of the station, I realize I never bought a monthly pass.  I bought spinach and ricotta and parmesan and taleggio and aged chevre and gelato, but no monthly pass.  I am the DUMBFUCKINGEST yuppie who ever lived.

conductor comes over.  he is not impressed by my ability to wring a whole $9.16 out of a couple crumped bills and a whole shitload of change at the bottom of my purse.  the fare to tuckahoe is $13.  I remember from painful personal experience that the conductor will take your driver's license information down for like fifteen minutes, while everyone around you looks at you like you're some smelly vagrant caught peeing between the cars, so that metro north can subsequently mail you a bill for the fare plus administrative overhead.  fuck that, I'm getting off at harlem 125th and buying a fucking pass.

cue all the jokes about a yuppie with a bagful of overpriced cheese wandering through harlem.  (though that's actually not fair since I've been there before a bunch and the station itself is pretty nice.)

except, that is, for the motherfucking monthly ticket machine.  which, of course, is out of order.

I buy a one-way ticket, bitching to myself the whole while, and head back up out to the oh-did-I-mention-freezing-fucking-cold train platform, to catch the train I was originally planning on catching anyway.

which is late.  fuckfuckfuck it's cold.  I decide to call steve and bitch to him, but a woman comes up to me (she's actually the same woman who told us to press the button in the elevator to get up to the platform, never minding the fact that it was already pressed) and tells me that my iPhone is going to give me an ear infection.

I tell her I already have a brain tumor.

she squints at me, very suspiciously, and actually BACKS AWAY.

so the best part of my day was when a crazy woman in harlem actually decided that *I* was more fucked-up than she was. 

these things don't happen every day, folks.  you have to treasure them.  I won't say it turned my mood around or anything but it helped.

so I'm moving offices again, which feels all kinds of weird.  the upside is that I finally get a fucking window again (my last two offices have been windowless, and even if I weren't prone to the odd week of totally hypochondriac SAD, well, it would STILL suck).  the downside is, I now have a view of a roof.  and, distantly, lots of a/c equipment.  woo!

still.  sunlight, people, sunlight.

the downside is it's been pretty nice to be one of the only people left on a hallway that was never very populous to begin with.  this was at its nicest for the first six months I was back at work after maternity leave (pumping breast milk is MUCH easier when no one even so much as walks by your locked door).  but -- shocking as this may be to believe -- I'm not entirely an extrovert.  I really, really like my space.  and my alone time.  and while I generally prefer to spend at least 90% of my waking hours being cheerful and social, there are those times when I really need to be alone and recharge.  unfortunately, if you're a happy chatty person most of the time, coworkers often get confused and annoyingly solicitous if you DARE shut your door.  "hey, is everything all right?  are you okay?"  rrgh.

the other downside is that it's also an office in a densely populated hall of people in my new group, all of whom have worked together for over a year now, and several of whom -- I am only now finding out -- really wanted my job and don't necessarily understand why I got it and they didn't.  oh, joy.  

I'm not complaining, since I've pretty psyched about the job and I don't think it's a mistake that I got it.  and I'm not so desperate yet that I feel like taking some of my former mentor's more wacky suggestions (including the one that I cut my hair so that I "look less pretty".  note that she did not say "young" or "unprofessional" or even "cute".  any of which would have prompted me to cut it.  but "less pretty"?  fuck that.  I draw the line at feeling bad for being pretty.)  for the most part they're a great group of folks and I'm looking forward to being part of a team that doesn't mostly sit out in groton, connecticut.  

and I don't generally mind coming in as the upstart newcomer.

but it's still weird.

- had a houseful of 40 people for james' first birthday party and of course the kid slept through it.  but hey, he wasn't allowed to have any cocktails anyway.

- got my cholesterol checked at work again today.  240.  the woman starts to give me the whole "you should modify your diet and start an exercise program" spiel, before she looks at the breakdown.  90LDL, 150HDL.  blink.  silence.  HAHAHAHA.  so of course I celebrated by going to the gym and having wild salmon for dinner.

- oh yes, and in related good work-type news, I am not laid off.  for now.  actually I got a fucking awesome job that is so cool I am still processing it and undoubtedly going to get laid off come september (see the bullet point two down).

- however, we still don't know if that means it's okay to have another kid now.  logic says no.  lesley says, fuck you, logic.  but logic generally wins.

- and also, let's be honest:  obviously wyzer inetgration happening at the end of the year makes everything interesting.

- james is 13 months and has four molars.  damn, kid!

- going to the cape next weekend for a nice valentine's day holiday.

- no interest in doing anything more tonight that doesn't involve cuddling, eating homemade apple crisp, or watching cheesy 80s movies.

I read a lot about facebooking one's exes, and googling one's exes (or being googled by them -- yup, have DEFINITELY had that happen to me*), and so on.  but it's rare to read a wholeheartedly, genuinely positive piece about the phenomenon.

(and, to be fair:  this ain't QUITE that piece.)

but!  I gave up years ago trying to convince my-ex's-and-my mutual friends that no, I REALLY do like my ex's wife.  (what?  I do!  and why wouldn't I like her?  she's fun, charming, gorgeous and level-headed.  so, I don't feel bad about my ex's taste in women.  and, he and I -- and technically she and steve -- all got married on the same day, so it's not like I'm wallowing in sorrow over being left behind or anything.)  well okay sure, fine, of course, I totally keep in mind the fact that it's very easy to put up a facebook profile of a REALLY REALLY HAPPY PERSON HONEST even when you may be anything but that.  (cf my earlier post.  and, a very good friend of mine.)

but!  again!  even beyond all that, theres something obscurely comforting, at least for me, in looking at the ex's facebook photos.  or, the ex's-wife's facebook photos.  because it kinds of reaffirms that, you know what?  we were both great cool, smart, fun people.  and we may not have been right for each other at the time.  (OH NO, we weren't.)  but it clearly didn't scar us, either, because look how cheerful and cute and wonderfully happy we both are now.


* I don't think it's stalking if it's mutually-friended-upon or whatever. on the contrary, under the right (non-stalker) circumstances, it can be pretty healthy and charming and downright cute.**


** no seriously.  I've gotten enough quasi-ex facebook/reconnecting requests that it's a little weird.  I KNOW it's not b/c I was that easy a person to date.  or live with.  as I'm sure steve can attest.

I write about helth-wyzer a lot.

but with today's announcements, and the rampant water cooler sniggering over how we might possibly change our name (which is NOT going to happen, it's an acquisition, not a merger, oh sure they are much the same but don't mindlessly equate them if you have any understanding of finance whatsoever, and oh by the way if you don't then please stop whingeing about the mortgage meltdown) I am head-shakingly amused at how much closer to that reality we are.


I will probably NOT get so drunk and depressed tonight as to go design subversive margaret atwood t-shirts on cafepress.com and then wear them under my nice banana republic suits and pretend that I'm really not a whiny passive-aggressive whore.  but you never know.

cf my earlier entry about the upside-down, crashed honda FIT, and my brief self-castigation over not stopping to help:  gosh, I'm glad I don't live in california.  or maybe I am glad after all, since if I lived there I'd probably STILL be patting myself on the back about not stopping to help.

(to be fair, I read about this weeks ago, but a recent salon blog post cum article on the topic has reminded me that hopefully no, I'm not off my rocker in being upset.)

this may seem odd, given how ostensibly public I am on facebook, and how infrequently I post here these days, but.....

....DAMN!

I had a great meeting today with a guy from work who also happens to me one of my friends on facebook.  of course I know this, and am (as much as I ever am) vaguely conscious of that when doing that oh so precious fucking little self-editing that ever takes place before I update my status.

but anyway.  he let slip a comment about [very controversial issue], and I let slip my enthusiastic agreement.

and he was all, "wow, you're [x position on this issue]?  really??  I never would've thought!  I read all your status updates!"


JESUS FUCKING CHRIST.


okay.  for the last time, people.


it's very fucking easy to over-reveal yourself on social networking sites, and services, like facebook and livejournal and so on.  it's really, totally, wildly, incredibly easy.  you're suddenly reconnected with all of these long-lost friends of yours . . . OR, you're so thrilled to be posting and commenting and sharing with a newfound community of friends. . . . that you forget that sometimes, sometimes, it takes longer to learn everything about your friends via web 2.0 than it does IRL.


but.


but!  LOTS of us under-reveal too.  or at least, we selectively reveal.  and so for those of us who are cautious enough to self-edit a lot of the time (okay fine not ALL the time), please please PLEASE do not assume that you know everything about us simply by reading our status updates.  or livejournal posts.  or work emails.  or whattheufckever.  because there are a whole fucking bunch of us who are web-savvy and technology-loving and not, well, you know, stupid.  and there's a distinct possibility that the stuff you see about us is EXACTLY WHAT WE WANT YOU TO SEE.

went out last night for the first time in a very long time, to a coworker's farewell party.  had a lot of fun, until the very end of the night, when another one of my coworkers got arrested for assault.

yeah.

as soon as his jaw heals and he can talk again, he's apparently calling a lawyer and suing the dudes he got in a fight with.  or possibly the bartender.  or both.

yeah.

it may be a while before I do any more work-related happy hours.

I think we now know better than to ever, ever try to fly a three-city itinerary over the holidays . . . because our flights were FINE.  no delays, no hassles, no nothing.  and there's no way we'd ever get that lucky if we ever tried to do it again.  so, while it was terrific to get to spend time with my family in NC, and then steve's family in minneapolis, I think christmas from here on out will involve one stay.  please.  because the baby was a peach throughout, but nevertheless it was a pretty long week.

minneapolis was a shockingly nice visit.  I did wipe out quite spectacularly on an icy sidewalk while going for a nice morning run, but that was more amusing than anything else, and once I moved onto the road I ended up with a really great workout.  mind you, my SIL was a total bitch to steve and her parents, but thankfully she didn't try to blame anything on me for a change, so I was finally allowed to sit back and ignore her drama.  it's about fucking time that taking the high road actually works out.  on a brighter note I got to meet my nephew for the first time ever.  he's adorable.  hard to believe that I'm an aunt; we only children tend to not count on these things.  speaking of which we're starting to think about giving james a sibling -- strangely enough I'm more hyped about the idea than steve, which is a complete reversal from a year ago.  (I LOVED being an only child.  but I do want another baby.)

also, in case anyone is wondering:  it is entirely possible to leave the house in yonkers at 7:39am and be sitting on your plane on the runway at la guardia at 8:26am.  do I recommend this?  fuck no.

I even warbled a couple lines of allman brothers as we drove through statesville.

so good to be here!  we all survived the flight (as did our passengers; despite the fact that james NEVER napped, he was miraculously still a peach) and it just feels great to be back home again.  not that anything is ever the same, year to year, but it's always lovely to come here once again.  also I really liked my cousin's girlfriend.  no, a LOT.  and james was a mad human whirling dervish and it was great to hear all the veteran parents be all, "oh my gosh, I can't believe how active he is!  [random cousin] was NEVER that busy!  I can't believe how you and steve have the energy to keep up with him!"

thank you.  neither do we.

merry early christmas and happy happy holidays everyone!

so the little neighbor baby boy, whose tears I soothed and nose I wiped and diapers I changed . . . ran in the triathlete at the olympics in beijing.

I knew this back in the summer, and cheered for him wildly.  and he did damn good.



now, I discover, his little brother (whose diapers I ALSO changed, and etc.!!) beat me in the 5k I ran in stow, massachusetts on thanksgiving day.

but okay, no, he didn't just beat me. (okay, tons and TONS of people beat me; dude, whatever, I was walking for a good piece of it.)

no, this awesome little kid came in first!!!

(me, I am number 337, alexandra spear, which is my cousin's name since I totally stole her entry.)

AND I AM SO STOKED FOR HIM!!!!! :) :) :)

you know your job and your holiday and quite possibly your life are all fucked up when you realize the only reason you're going to a christmas party after work -- the ONLY reason -- is that you think it might be good for your career.

The Five Love Languages

My primary love language is probably
Words of Affirmation
with a secondary love language being
Physical Touch.

Complete set of results

Words of Affirmation: 10
Physical Touch: 8
Quality Time: 6
Receiving Gifts: 5
Acts of Service: 1


Information

Unhappiness in relationships, according to Dr. Gary Chapman, is often due to the fact that we speak different love languages. Sometimes we don't understand our partner's requirements, or even our own. We all have a "love tank" that needs to be filled in order for us to express love to others, but there are different means by which our tank can be filled, and there are different ways that we can express love to others.

Take the quiz , speaking as someone who's very word-oriented as well as fiercely independent, I didn't find the results surprising.

aka, "ooh, look!  flying car!"

westchester county's highways generally suck when it's raining, as half of them usually get closed due to flooding.  (why the county with some of the highest property taxes in america can't fucking afford better drainage systems is anyone's guess.)  so this morning the bronx river parkway was closed, meaning I and pretty much everyone else had to merge back onto the sprain parkway and stay there for a little longer.  the sprain is a pretty fast-moving road in the morning, and because the bronx river parkway is an even faster road, this basically meant a lot of speeding cars had to suddenly and unexpectedly merge back into a long line of similarly speeding cars.  in the rain.

steve had already gone up ahead of me, since he never gets off at the bronx river parkway anyway.  therefore he didn't get to see what I saw two minutes later:  a honda fit miraculously rising up up and away four cars in front of me, like the driver and his/her lucky car had somehow been called to The Rapture.

then it fell back to earth.

then came the crash, and the squealing, and the sound of glass shattering.

then the horns. 

I didn't realize until the horns started that I'd already braked and pulled as far away as I could.  glad I did, though, because the car next to me wound up rear-ending the car in front of it.

anyway, for something that only happened four cars away, it took a while to see anything.  by the time the traffic started parting around the now-upside-down and badly crumpled -- but empty -- honda, there was a girl standing on the right side of the road, and a guy standing on the median talking on his cell phone.  I asked the girl if she was okay -- she said she was fine and not to worry.

and while I now wish that I'd pulled over and at least given her my coat or something anyway -- what if she'd been in shock?? -- the rapidly-approaching traffic behind us was starting to back up and look dangerous (lots more stomped-on brakes and squealing tires and shimmying cars) and all I could really think about was the fact that I didn't want to park my car *with james in it* anywhere near this mess.  and then by the time I pulled over somewhere that looked safer, there were two more cars behind me already pulled over with people getting out of them and going over to her.  so I settled for calling 911 and reporting it (even though the guy on the cell phone on the median was undoubtedly doing just that).


steve and I have always figured that we'd see something like this happen eventually, given the shitty driving (and roads) in our area.  we'd always just hoped that it wouldn't INVOLVE us directly.  luckily this one didn't, and honestly the only important thing in my mind is that james is entirely safe and sound. 

but I am spending today at home nevertheless.

the great thing about facebook, imho, is NOT the fact that you can suddenly reconnect with old friends from high school with whom you've unfortunately lost touch. . . .

. . . . the GREAT thing is that you can reconnect with them, wonder why you lost touch. . . .

. . . . then read their status updates and think to yourself, "wow, no WONDER we're not close anymore!"



there are undoubtedly tons of people on facebook at this moment who would probably say that about me.  so what?  if facebook gives people a little closure in their lives that's hardly a bad thing.

p.s.  does it count as passive-aggressive if the people I'm talking about don't read my journal?  hmm, I think not.

I am facing the very real prospect of a weekend with no set plans.  BOO.  YA!   :)

(mind you there is a birthday party tonight on the LES that I really, really wanted to go to.  on the other hand, steve really didn't, and unfortunately he wins since our babysitter has the SATs tomorrow morning, and even I'm not irresponsible enough to say that she should *start* a babysitting gig at 9pm the night before.)

it's not that we don't have anything to do this weekend (hah!) but it's a weekend of nothing but baby and spouse and house puttering.  if we hit the indian place or the mall that will likely be our sum total of excitement for the day.  I am totally kvelling.



and in conclusion, once again, words to live by from overheardinnewyork:  "My father always told me, 'Never run away from a fight. If the guy's bigger than you, hit him. If he gets back up, hit him again. If he gets back up again, hit him with a garbage can. If he still gets back up, run like hell, 'cause this dude's gonna kill you!'"
shamelessly stolen from  , a list of words invented by shakespeare.  very fun reading.

.....when you're lame like me and don't like twitter but still post a relentless onslaught's worth of status updates each day.....

.....but like a dumbass you have accepted FB friend requests from coworkers.....

.....you can NOT, sadly, post the following:



"Lesley realizes, to her chagrin, that yes, they really DO pay her enough for this shit."

so there was this huge debacle at work a couple months ago where I totally bitched out this woman and her group for utterly failing to do their jobs.  some stuff wound up getting escalated (NOT my fault) and there was a nice big meeting to cool everyone down, and I managed to get all my pissiness off my chest while simultaneously volunteering to help them fix their fuckup.

I'd been thinking for months that everyone in that group totally hated me.  and hey, maybe they did.  but actually it turns out that that woman and several of her staff have requested that I join her group in the upcoming reorg.

even weirder, I totally want to.



the baby is on his third nap of the day.  he's growing like a weed and utterly amazing.  he even put up with the shrieking hordes at the macy's in yonkers this afternoon, which was nearly more than I myself could do.  so far in the last ten and a half months I have only ONCE yielded to temptation and deliberately run the stroller wheels over someone's foot (and oh YES did that woman deserve it).  today I resisted the urge even after some random woman emptied half her purse onto my poor unsuspecting baby.  james is young enough that I don't think it would have scarred him for life, ethically speaking, if I'd let him keep her wallet.  nevertheless our consciences are clear.

A: What accessories do you wear everyday?

my wedding rings.  also a silver elsa perretti madonna necklace that steve got me when james was born.  also, usually, an antique silver ring with lots of tiny stones, on my right hand.   I used to wear earrings constantly, but I have such a hard time finding any that look right with the necklace that these days I usually just don't bother.


B: What is your beauty routine?

shower, put moisturizer/sunscreen on my face, blow dry hair.  if I'm home I put leave-in conditioner on the ends; if I'm at the office gym, which is more likely, I spritz some cheap hairspray on.


C: What was the last item of clothing (for yourself) that you purchased?

a pair of 7 for all mankind jeans


D: Do you use a dresser, closet, or both?

both.  multiple closets in fact, much of whose clothes I never wear -- I haven't gotten rid of any clothes since freshman year of college (and really, really should).


E: What type of earrings are in your ears right now?

none


F: What type of figure do you have (measurements)?

32-24-34.  at least that's what it was pre-baby.  I haven't had the guts to measure since.


G: Do you wear glasses?

only for about 30 seconds morning and evening, before/after I put in/take out my10 diopter contacts


H: What type of handbag do you carry?

nice big caramel-colored bag from banana republic.  it's a little oversized, but I love it b/c I can fit EVERYTHING in it.  baby toys, pacifiers, umbrella, book, laptop, all at once.


I: What is your ideal style?

kinda preppy casual.  one or two nice pieces (in case you hadn't noticed I am a total label whore) and clean, simple everything else.


J: What is your favorite brand of jeans?

this month?  citizens of humanity.  7s and paige are nice too.


K: Do you wear knee-hi stockings?

ick, no


L: Do you *have* to wear matching lingerie?

I guess not, but it does kinda bug me when I don't match


M: Do you wear makeup?

I almost always powder my nose, but otherwise I don't wear anything unless I'm going out at night


N: Do you wear nightgowns?

never.   big fan of flannel pajamas though.


O: What outerwear do you put on when going out on a typical winters day?

nice coat, nice scarf. I want a pair of nice leather gloves, and I probably should wear a hat but they generally mess up my hair even more than winter wind does.


P: What is your favorite perfume?

opium by YSL.   also london by burberry and jess by jesssica mcclintock.


Q: Is your motto "quality over quantity" when it comes to clothing and accessories?

it should be.  it's certainly what I aspire to, but . . . sometimes you spill coffee on your work blouse and there's nothing to be done except trot over to the gap or h&m.


R: Do you wear rain boots?

nope


S: Do you wear socks or slippers when your feet get cold?

nice shearling slippers


T: Do you have a set of travel luggage?

yeah . . . somewhere. . . .


U: What is your daily uniform?

tailored slacks, a nice non-iron button down shirt, mid-heel loafers and a nice coat


V: If you are married, did you wear a veil with your wedding dress? If not, how did you do your hair?

yup, I wore a veil -- what the hell, right?  :)


W: Do you wear a watch?

not generally.  I have a pricey heirloom watch that my grandmother gave me, but I tend to only wear that on dressy occasions.   I also have a bunch of my deceased aunt's watches, but they're wind-up and that drives me bonkers.  so mostly my watch = my cellphone.


X: What item of clothing always makes you feel beautiful?

hell, anything.   a nice skirt and heels generally does the trick.  so does stealing one of steve's shirts.


Y: What is your favorite type of yarn?

the very very fine gauge kind that goes into a nicely tailored 3/4-sleeve sweater for me.


Z: Do you prefer zippers or buttons?

depends, I suppose....?

You Are Eggnog
Rich, sweet, and probably a little drunk. Everyone who knows you tends to get a little fatter.
What Holiday Food Are You?

came home early yesterday afternoon to surprise steve with a nice romantic friday night date night.  prepped dinner, cleaned the place up, got out all the candles and so on, and then decided to mend an old slip from our grad school days.

found a mending kit and felt very thrifty and virtuous as I mended the slip and two fine gauge sweaters.  (I can sew perfectly well, but who sews anymore??  that's what the tailor in the chrysler building is for.)

tried on the mended slip, went into the hallway for just a second to twirl around and make sure it still fit.

came back:  max was trying to swallow the needle.


needless to say (no that it not a pun) he succeeded, despite my best efforts.  so, one romantic friday night date at home wound up being a seven hour odyssey at the vet's office (first half me, second half steve).  we went to bed at about 1am.  steve is back there with him now this morning.


when this is all over and max is fine, I'll laugh.  but we're not quite there yet.

....I know it's b/c the NFL network sucks balls, and they can't do HD sound right, but I'm still REALLY hoping that Jada is swapping out the lyrics for cuss words.

if the fucking NFL network keeps this up I'm gonna be cussing too.

in case you hadn't realized, I LOVE the NFL.

I also LOVE pottery barn.

I do NOT, however, love the combination enough to even consider plunking down $20+ on pottery barn's NFL glassware collection.

and if I won't, who will?  think of the glassware, people!



okay, so I did consider it.  but only after a couple beers yesterday, drunk out of non-football affiliated glasses I might add.

after having some poor guy come out to give us an estimate on central air (which, btw -- score!), we wound up getting a new boiler instead.

lest we sound stupider and more sucker-iffic than we actually are, let me at least point out that the dude was totally happy to sell us insulation for the attic . . . but said we didn't need it.  he was totally happy to sell us new upstairs windows* . . . but said those weren't the problem.

on the other hand, when we whined about how the upstairs never got warm, no matter how high we turned up the thermostat, in complete violation of the basic law of thermodynamics, god bless the guy for noticing that two of the eight burners on our current undersized, eighteen-year-old boiler are mysteriously missing.  just, gone.  poof.

we thought we had already found every dumbass thing wrong with this house that its former owners had left us.  wrong size windows upstairs?  check.  all kitchen appliances, plus dining room, plus family room, all on one circuit?  check.  shower head set a mere 5'5" above the tub floor?  hideous fake paneling literally glued to the wall?  hideous acoustic tile literally glued to the ceiling?  beautiful inlaid mahogany floors painted over where the bookshelves are?  three inches of concrete and chicken wire behind the ugly blue tile in the upstairs bathroom?  a powder room so small that a skinny 5'4" woman can barely squeeze inside?  check, check, check, check, check.  and check.

but a boiler that's automatically 25% wasted?  that was news.  jeeee-sus.

. . . . well, here's to not having to bundle the baby up like nanook of the fucking north every time we put him down for the night.



* the upstairs windows are, technically, new.  the listing for our house even said "new windows upstairs" and this was entirely correct.  also entirely correct, however, is the fact that the fucking things DON'T FIT the frames but instead leave an inch or so of gap at the top.  we have put insulating foam in the gap and are vastly relieved to discover that this stopgap measure really is working.

this "public" journal is such a comparatively more private place (e.g., very few of my FB friends even know about it) that I find it odd to be so at a loss in terms of things to say here.

clearly, I can still do tongue-tied with the best of them, however.

but oh yes that's right, in terms of post-worthy items, Yes We Did!  :) 

voting with the baby in yonkers was very trippy and fun.  I couldn't get a picture of james pulling the lever as he was manifestly uninterested in the machine.  for once, jesus.  however, steve and I spent the whole walk home getting all giddy when we told him that HE WAS THERE when mommy and daddy voted for obama.

unfortunately I spent the actual election night in a hotel room in groton, CT.  actually, that's not fair -- I spent much of the beginning of election night at a really awesome hole-in-the-wall, all-homemade pasta place on the water in groton which TOTALLY rocked. green checked tablecloth and a deck out back overlooking the ocean covered only in plastic tarp and all. very fun. and as a bonus, drinking with the brits this time luckily didn't involve any embarrassing shenanigans in grand central.

the rest of the night, of course, was spent in the hotel room on the phone with steve.

BUT, why do I love new england? because god love good people at the starbucks in the mystic marriott, who told me they wouldn't give me free coffee even though I had voted, since it was illegal to do so....

....WHICH IT WAS!!!!!!!!....

....but then winked and gave me one anyway.

god bless you, new england.  YOU know what this country is about.

the baby slept from 10am to 1pm today.  

then went down again at 2:30pm.  

it is now 3pm.

he slept five hours a day both days of last weekend.  I know he doesn't get much of a nap in daycare, and I'm sure he's growing again, but jesus christ this is ridiculous.

I feel like he's regressed to newborn sleep habits.  this is bizarre when at ten months he is such a hugely amazing creature that I fall more in love with him every day.

manager training was, no fooling, awesome.  also totally frustrating given all the uncertainty around my job, but hey, you can't have everything.  and while I am facing the very real prospect of losing my job over the next six months, the fact remains that I still have one (and my mortgage is paid on time and all that jazz) so I won't whine toooooo much.  I would whine even less if my 401k didn't more closely resemble a 101k, though.

anyway, the best part of training was the first morning, when we were divided up into teams and given index cards and masking tape, to see who could build the tallest free-standing tower.  dumb old me totally ruined the learning for everyone (turns out one of the other teams had been deliberately set up to win -- exactly how, was the learning) when I decided we could make the tower taller simply by stacking the conference room tables on top of each other.  (actually my first idea was to stack a table on top of a table on top of another table, then put a chair on, then have someone stand on the chair, then have him or her hold up an easel upon which was balanced the tower.  I guess the fact that the chair was on wheels had some people getting all squeamish.  whatever; it's not like I didn't volunteer to stand on the chair for christ's sake.)

it's a blustery, drizzly day, and we're wasting a nice windy night by the fire by driving up to sudbury around suppertime.  the original plan was to head out right around james' bedtime, but given that he's on his SECOND marathon nap of the day, we may be leaving later than I'd intended.

in related news I think I was seated near the absolute dregs of humanity on the train to work friday morning and am still trying to shake the shivers.  I'd burn my clothes if I weren't exceptionally fond of the outfit.

I could talk about the past couple weeks, but the pats are playing and I don't have much time.  so we'll start with yesterday, and backfill later perhaps:

spent much of sunday in brooklyn w/tyler, loving her new pad.  brought her and the baby and a couple six packs over to the red hook ball fields so steve and I could get one more hit of pupusas before the season ends.  (of course there's apparently an awesome pupusa place just down the street from us, but it doesn't involve driving ALL THE WAY along manhattan from one end to the other, so we'll save that for winter.)  also found it vastly amusing to wander around red hook drinking pumpkin ale in public while pushing a stroller and valiantly trying not to jaywalk.  when I win the award for Worst Mother Ever I'll know it's moments like these that made it happen.  hah.

have a Mom's Night Out this thursday at the local westchester fondue restaurant.  there's nothing that's not awesome about that (esp. since I missed the last one, which was at p.f. chang's) so you know I'll be there with bells on.  even though I will be coming off of three days worth of manager training by then.  (nothing says "pour me a drink" like three days of learning how not to make fun of your direct reports' outfits.)  the really amusing thing in all this is that my company is going through a major reorg (yes again) and my own job is not at all a sure thing (yes again).  so this whole manager training thing is really only useful if I wind up staying at helth-wyzer and make director.  otherwise, it's three days in the paradise that is rye brook, new york.  I've recently decided to [accept james' decision and] wean the baby somewhat, so at least I won't suffer too much if I'm not able to chain myself up to the machine and drain the lizards three times a day.  rrgh.

we are apparently going to a late-night halloween party with a superhero theme.  I am in favor of this except for the fact that I want to be running my 5k much, much faster than 35 minutes before I put on tights and thigh-high boots.  also it starts at 10pm.  hmm.

in related news, I love sammy morris.  and randy moss is still tops in my book too.  woo!

okay, done.  bye.

it's a weird case of deja vu . . . which catalog am I reading, again??

as steve points out, looks like everyone went to the same stores in north carolina huh?



* a crate and barrel nightstand, yes, I admit it

note to all:

it is way, WAY more fun to read about the election when for whatever reason you perennially mistake "undecided" for "undead."


pirate facebook may be slightly funnier.  or it may not.

got my wish, hit my stride, found my dream job, and of course all hell is in the process of sloooooooowly breaking loose.  hopefully it is doing so slowly enough to allow me to still have my job in a year.

I feel like I've been living my life on other people's facebook walls for the past three months.  probably because, mostly, I have.

I went to a happy hour / birthday party a couple weeks ago where eleven of the sixteen attendees called in sick the next day.  the fact that I myself did not can be chalked up to mere chance.  that, and the judicious choice of which train to take out of grand central.  and, my (albeit drunken) command of spanish when the cabbie misheard "valley road" for "valhalla".

last weekend in ithaca was great albeit quite trippy.  you haven't lived till you've walked from collegetown to east hill plaza at three in the morning.

james is drinking from a cup and refusing to nurse at night.  this definitely makes my nightly wine regimen easier but has the unfortunate side effect of getting me all weepy and worried that he's weaning.  whatever.  the kid does everything else early so why not this?

we are watching the presidential debate tonight b/c I have high hopes that really really good willamette valley pinot noir can curb the urge to throw baby toys at the TV and shriek in frustration.  today was the last day at work for a phenomenally terrific client of mine who, having adjusted to be laid-off with the utmost of cheer and dare I say it snark, is now volunteering for the obama campaign in florida.  so our last status meeting was taken up by impassioned, heated, unanimous agreement as to the multitude of detriments of mccain and, especially, palin.  this, when all the other participants were all middle-aged white marketers with MBAs.  hah.  I KNEW my degree wasn't an automatic ticket straight to hell.  rather, I have many, many years of hard work ahead of me before I get my ticket, bitches.
I can NOT keep driving out to groton and back.  if for no other reason than, I will someday get a really, REALLY whopping ticket.

sarah palin has five children, the youngest five months old.  not that it's any of our business, but I wonder what her personal position on family planning is?  meaning, is she (not not) planning on having any more in the next four years? 


please notice that I am not going anywhere NEAR whether or not she should.  this is idle speculation, not pointed or leading or rhetorical.

had a nice weekend of gender role reversals, for once -- steve watched the baby and made him two week's worth of baby food while I took a bunch of doors off their hinges and repainted them.  (okay, I only had time to prime them.  painting is tonight.  woo frickin' hoo.)  sometimes I think we get more done when we're not trying; we deliberately set out to NOT work on the house or anything else this weekend, since steve's leaving this afternoon for four days in london and we wanted to get in some quality time.  what ended happening, of course, is that we had a perfect weekend of all-three-of-us family time AND got a whole boatload of stuff done.  go figure.  let's hear it for low expectations I guess.  oh and park hill is GORGEOUS in the early fall.

I'm in my usual place as I face a week away from steve:   I love being able to cuddle and play with the baby, and there's a ton of stuff I can get done around the house in the evenings*.  at the same time, I am really going to miss the extra help getting everyone ready and out the door in the mornings, and frankly -- call me crazy -- I'm going to miss steve too.  helping with the whole lonely part is tyler, coming over to stay the night wednesday, which has me irrationally excited.  you hate to burst your best friend's bubble and reveal how pathetically mundane your life of parenting in suburbia is . . . but there's nothing wrong with sushi and and wine and crappy movies, and it gives me an extra kick in the butt about vacuuming the basement.  (cf my earlier glee at having the time to do housework.)

besides, I can plan a nice menu for a welcome home dinner friday night.  that is, when I get over this nasty cold that our plague monkey son has bestowed upon us.  sniffle!  I love you, james.  :)



* I think I'm making it it sound like we're still doing major renovation work on the house.  we're not -- or at least, not right now!  but with both steve and I working full-time, and with a beautiful eight-month-old baby boy who's crawling, cruising, babbling, eating solid foods, and into literally EVERYTHING he can get his chubby little fingers on, there are an awful lot of general housekeeping chores that simply fall by the wayside in the mere hour or two we have each night to ourselves.  call me crazy but I'd rather hug my husband and eat dinner and watch the daily show with him than, you know, fold laundry.  so the byproduct of a happy marriage is a whole ton of little nitpicky chores that are just waiting to pounce on us the moment we have some spare time.

I got called out on facebook for excessive potty mouth.  and not undeservedly I might add.  so my entire day and a half of unremitting douchebaggery, asshattery, and tomfoolery will henceforth be referred to in only the cleanest and sauvest and smooth-as-a-babys-bottom of tones.  HAH.  meaning, my day sucked like a hoover attached to my son's diaper.

steve has plans to teach james how to ski this winter.  this is not entirely out of line with his "if you can walk, you can ski" philosophy, as I will be shocked if james isn't walking by winter.  fuck, I'll be shocked if he's not walking by halloween.  (whoops; see above, clean and suave.)  but when are where we are supposed to get the time and money to ski, I'd like to know.  (no, no sarcasm, I would like to know.  because I'd really like to go skiing dammit!)



ooh, clearly time to revisit the first paragraph's resolution.  also, it's supposed to rain on saturday which kind of scotches our picnic plans to take a couple bottles of wine and go hang with fellow parents (okay yes fine and our kids too) in central park.  we would ordinarily still go ahead with it rain be damned, but I think drunken mud fights lose some of their luster when your eight-month-old is looking on.

me, in a nutshell.

wow, firefox no longer even remembers the livejournal update link in my history.  it HAS been a while, hasn't it.

I feel like facebook is the poor man's livejournal.  I have to repress the urge to simply reprint my last 20 status entries here.

you're right, I did totally say "status entries" as a way of avoiding the decision:  "stati"?  "statii"?  statuses"?

james eats most everything these days but was not entirely sure about cilantro-jalapeno chutney at the local indian restaurant.  he had this look on his face like, "oh jesus, mom, are you sure?  really?  what IS this?  are you sure I can eat it?"  I mean, he didn't spit it out, but you could tell he was totally considering it.

whenever I feel like a bad mom, I should remember to hit the westchester mall on labor day.  all the money in the world can't buy empathy.  or, apparently, class.

but speaking of which I am waiting for half a million dollars in funding for my project at helth-wyzer.  that is more than we paid for our house.  I am smart enough not to compare the relative ROIs of each in my head, at night, with steve snoring beside me and the baby silent on the monitor.  um, mostly.

I had literally the best mexican food that I can remember, or at least the best since my 2 weeks in the yucatan back in 2000, at the red hook ball fields on sunday.  and it wasn't mexican food at all really but various kinds of south american.  oh, and awesome.  I'm not entirely sure the pupusas ENTIRELY lived up to their hype.  but they were incredible.  and steve liked the soccer.  next time we need to go back with a twelve-pack of corona and a picnic blanket.  also, odds are, next time we go back james will be walking.  since the little bugger is not only crawling but cruising up a storm.  and starting to launch himself at objects that are out of cruising distance. 

I am not ready to go to work tomorrow.


SMITHERS, RELEASE THE HOUNDS!

I don't really know what to post.  my job is awesome.  my baby is awesome.  my husband is awesome.  my house is, dare I say it, awesome.  the combination of all four doesn't suck my will to live but it sure as hell takes every fucking minute of my day.

I've taken to working from home on fridays (note the lack of quotes; I'm generally doing real helth-wyzer work about 90% of the time, which to be honest is probably a higher percentage than when I'm in the office) just so I can get shit done around the house.  there are so many different ways that this is sad, I won't bother to enumerate them.  except, it keeps me sane.

I can run a full half-hour at 6mph these days.  that's three 10-minute miles.  I'm sure all you serious runners out there are laughing in your adidas at me, but it makes me proud.  especially when the aforementioned job means I don't get to run very much as it is.  (BUT it's like the only time I get to blow-dry my hair, so I can ALMOST count it in my mental ledger as a job-necessary chore.)


oh and, wish me luck.  we're flying out to minneapolis tomorrow morning at 6:15am.  am I happy?  of course not.  am I resigned?  well, yes, after six months (and this whole thing being my idea in the first place), yes I am.  am I too fucking glad that we're flying first class and I get free champagne the whole way?  no, no I'm not.  because you can't BE too glad to get champagne at six fucking fifteen ack emma in the goddamn motherfucking morning.  and oh by the way, yes that's right, keep it coming.

I spilled some latte on the floor this weekend at starbucks, then in essence blamed the baby and said it was spit-up.  (for all of you out there that are castigating me for this:  you know you would do exactly the same thing if you had a baby.)

also, he's seven months old and won't be scarred by this.  other things, yes.  this, no.

also, I spilled latte on the floor to avoid spilling it ON THE BABY INSTEAD when jostled by a rather emo-looking 25-year-old.  and if you're 25 and still all emo, you need to get a life and stop hanging around fucking bronxville on a beautiful saturday morning.  jesus christ.  I half suspect he was wearing brooks brothers too.

tons of not-wholly-lame stuff to post about but I don't feel like it right now.  however:  saw my old high school girlfriend* way back in november (weekend of my baby shower) and we had an absolute blast catching up.  mostly b/c, well, she's awesome.  but anyway, I was mildly amused to hear how another friend of ours (and now only a friend of hers**) is doing.  apparently said girl was still with her college boyfriend and about to buy a house with him.  I'm ashamed to report that I made some comment to steve later like, "yeah, she's a mess.  I give them a year, tops."

um.  saw that same girlfriend last week and yup, the other girl and her boy have since broken up.  not happy to be right.  not happy that I'm mildly amused, either.



* I tend to use the term "girlfriend" to mean "good friend of mine who's a girl", just in case anyone's reading this and thinks I was way cooler in high school than I actually was.

** originator of the second (there are only two) evil letters I've ever received.  the first one was much better, really, because it contained the words "you two can go fuck like rabbits for all I care."  but for the record, we didn't.

multitasking is:  being on a conference call . . . at home . . . while your baby is napping . . . and you are taping and priming baseboards in the master bedroom.

this is the "working from home, parallel processing day".  as opposed to the sequentiality of every other day this week:  bring the baby with me to work on the train, drop him off at daycare and go do work, take him out at lunchtime for a doctor's appt (okay this only happened once), bring him back to the office and go do work, bring him back home on the train, get dinner ready, put him down to bed, eat dinner, and finally, get to work on the master bedroom and new baby bedroom (taping, priming, painting, vaccuming).

steve has helped with various parts of this.  but still.  I am BURNED.  OUT.


* okay, so my life doesn't really suck at all, actually.  in recent weeks I've even been thrilled with it.  but THIS week?  fuck yeah.

(alternate subject line:  there's a bathroom on the right.)


screwing with your baby 101:  lesson one, playing folk songs in the car

the best verse of "poor howard" is the one that goes, "jay arthur rank with a great big gong".  because steve can change "gong" to "dong", "schlong" or, my personal fave, "bong".  

but that usage of "bong" pales beside hearing my husband warble, at the chorus, "left us here, TO SMOKE THIS BONG!" as our six-month-old baby giggles in the background.

luckily it's an obscure enough folk song that I don't think he'll get in trouble at daycare if/when he learns to repeat us.


(and yes, tyler, I fully expect to teach him to sing "the girl with colitis goes by.")
